Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 3: Prevention & Control of Infectious Disease (Including Immunizations)

Exclusion:
When A Child Becomes Ill And Is Sent Home Or Denied Attendance

When a child becomes ill but does not require immediate medical attention, a child care provider must decide if the child should be sent home.

Most illnesses do NOT require exclusion. One also needs to be aware that exclusion is not effective in many situations. Frequently individuals can carry and transmit a germ without being ill themselves. There is also the incubation period, the time between exposure and the beginning of symptoms, when a child can transmit a disease before they show symptoms and become ill.

There are three key criteria that pediatricians recommend be used when determining whether or not a child should be excluded from care due to illness.

  • Prevents Child from Participating

    If the child is not able to participate comfortably in activities.

  • Results In Need For Care Greater Than Child Care Provider(s) Can Provide Without Affecting Others

    If keeping the child in care results in a need for care that is greater than child care provider or providers can provide without compromising the health and safety of other children.

  • Poses A Risk Of Spread Of Harmful Disease To Others

    If the child could spread a harmful disease or illness to another child.

*See the CFOC4 link for the American Academy of Pediatrics recommendations related to if children should be excluded for specific symptoms.

This is found in Appendix A (pg. 453-457)- Signs and Symptoms Chart. This is an excellent resource to use when deciding whether to exclude a child for illness. The link to this can be found in the support material at the end of the chapter.
